Award.AwardTitle: Chemical Bonding Across the Periodic Table
Award.AbstractNarration:
Roald Hoffmann is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in research that melds chemical and physical approaches to the prediction of new structures, properties and reactivity across the periodic table, and especially matter under extreme conditions of pressure. The problems being explored range across all of chemistry, from hydrogen to astatine. In the realm of high pressure, the work is exploring the possible stability of SiO (not familiar quartz, SiO2), the potential superconductivity of species as diverse as AuO (with a so-called mixed valence transition between two forms of gold in the structure), and Li- or H-doped NbN, to molecular acetylenes and ferrocene under pressure. In order to gain further insight into the world in-between the molecular and the macro, the work is exploring the interplay of polarity and dimensionality in low-dimensional CdSe and NaCl arrays, looking at how to stabilize the silicon analogue of graphene, and exploring potential metallic micelles. Since prediction is the best test of understanding, the research sets out to design as yet unmade molecular and extended systems, including some nonclassical organometallics, untypical organoiodides, novel networks containing both tetrahedral and square-planar main group atoms, and the possible formation of O-O bonds in oxides.

Chemistry is to be found in the properties of persistent groupings of atoms, of molecules. From their changeable combinations comes the incredible variety of organic and inorganic chemistry at the center of the art, craft, business and science of chemistry. And moving out from this center one encounters the still greater richness of biological function and materials with unusual properties, as chemistry touches and affects the rest of the world. The molecular science continues to surprise in the shape of one molecule, in the reactivity of another, in the unusual electric or magnetic properties of a third. But we have a way to go to understanding, in the qualitative yet productive way chemists have of parlaying experience into the making of the new. The proposed research addresses this need for understanding, especially in the behavior of matter under pressures such as those at the center of the earth (attainable in a few laboratories as well). Addressing a range of bonding situations across the periodic table, from hydrogen to the actinides, this proposal uses quite specific bonding puzzles as a springboard to build frameworks of understanding that chemists and physicists can take away and themselves design new molecules and new extended structures (of the type found in minerals, diamond, metals). Such molecules might have interesting and important properties, high temperature superconductivity just one of them. Risky, specific, predictions of the existence of molecules and extended systems, and their structures and properties -- the best test of real understanding in chemistry is a hallmark of the work being performed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemistry is the art, craft, business, and science of substances and their transformations. And, in a parallel microscopic perspective,  the substances are now seen in the mind’s eye (and through our instruments) as molecules. Chemistry is an experimental science, yet in it, as in other fields of science, computation and theory have become more and more important. Edisonian approaches, the next molecule off the shelf, are giving way, as they must, to design. Then there is an active role for the theoretician.

          Within theory and computation in chemistry and physics (and not just there) there is a tension, between simulation and understanding. Getting the facts right, that color or reactivity exactly predicted, is important.  But understanding is something more -- perforce qualitative, a  panoply of verbal arguments, buttressed by chemical symbols and some equations, that allows one to reason how the molecule might be modified to…  get it to be what one wants. In a case we studied, we learned to see that the degree to which two electrons exist uncoupled from other electrons in the molecule (their socalled diradical character) is related to  not one but several desired properties   -- in our case to the ability of the molecule to emit two bursts of light instead of one, and to form a special barrier to the transmission of electric current across the molecule, and to easily rip off a hydrogen from another molecule.

          I have a track record for constructing general frameworks of understanding of molecules across the periodic table, organic or inorganic. In recent years people have used high pressure to make new combinations of the elements. The new compositions are important, and they may have practical consequences – the world record high critical temperature superconductor is for a material, probably SH3, at over 2 million atmospheres.  With my able collaborators I have looked at many specific high pressure problems, trying to make sense of the new compositions of matter that result. For instance, if you compress metallic sodium it turns at some pressure transparent, losing its metallic character. It has been figured out that what one has then is a so-called electride, with an electron pushed off the metal into the nooks and crannies between the atoms that pressure creates. So one no longer has a metal, but an ionic compound, like NaCl. But instead of positive Na ions and negative chlorides, as one has in table salt, this compressed crystal has sodium ions and electrons in cavities.

          Superconductivity has been mentioned. It has been one of the my goals to get a predictive theory, one that takes advantage of chemical intuition, of superconductivity. Somehow the motions of the electrons in the substance are influenced by very specific motions of the lattice of atomic nuclei. A project my group has done on compounds of gold and hydrogen, with some important activation from alkali metals, provides some clues as to what needs in a good superconductor. In another project, not yet finished, two postdoctoral associates in my group have come up with a simple cubic phosphorus crystal that is both superconducting and easy to analyze. The hope is that this system will serve like the fruit fly or C. elegans worm for biologists – a structure (an element, under pressure) simple enough to learn from.

          Broader impacts: Outside of chemistry, the primary impact of  our work is on physics and materials science. Our continued advocacy, though realistic examples, of the value of a chemical perspective, of bonds and bands, has been influential. The field of high pressure research inherently brings together chemists and physicists, and if one can make useful interpretations and predictions from a  chemical perspective, people listen.

          By being a writer, of poetry, plays and essays, I feel I have also brought science to a much wider group of people. I note an important essay on citation practice, a linchpin of our scientific microsociety, in Angewandte Chemie.  In a different direction in a lecture, just last month,  I looked at the many ways of diversity in chemistry, in biology, and in the ways of people working perforce together. There are good reasons to value continuity and conservation, but  in the end I argued both on philosophical and social grounds for the value of diversity, in science, in its practitioners, and in society.

          Once a month I run a kind of cabaret, called “Entertaining Science”,  at a Greenwich Village café. At least one person in it is a scientist, at least one an entertainer. For instance, tomorrow (Oct. 1), a planetary scientist, Caleb Scharf is paired with an accordion-based jazz group, the Yorkvillians, that has two composed two pieces based on planetary science for the occasion.  We have fun, but more than that, science is somehow humanized.
